description: Theory of attitude change explaining how people process persuasive messages through central or peripheral routes

boundary_conditions: Recipient must have measurable prior attitude

authors_empirical_claims.claim: High motivation and ability lead to central route processing
Central route produces more persistent attitude change
authors_empirical_claims.specific_statistic: Attitudes persisted 2+ weeks vs <1 week for peripheral

entities.name: persuasive_message
entities.description: Communication designed to change recipient attitudes

properties.name: argument_strength
properties.description: Quality of reasoning and evidence presented

operationalization.measurement_approach: Identify logical reasoning, evidence quality, coherence
boundary_rules: Strong: logical structure + credible evidence + coherent reasoning
Weak: logical fallacies OR poor evidence OR incoherent reasoning
validation_examples: Strong: 'Studies show X because researchers found Y in controlled conditions'
Weak: 'Everyone knows X' or 'X is obvious'

properties.name: peripheral_cues
properties.description: Non-argument factors that may influence attitudes

operationalization.measurement_approach: Identify source credibility, attractiveness, popularity indicators
boundary_rules: Must be external to message content logic
validation_examples: Source expertise: 'According to Dr. Smith, leading researcher...'
Attractiveness: Visual or social appeal cues

entities.name: message_recipient
entities.description: Individual receiving and processing persuasive message

properties.name: motivation_to_process
properties.description: Recipient's willingness to engage with message content

operationalization.measurement_approach: Assess personal relevance, interest, engagement indicators
boundary_rules: High: direct personal relevance or explicit engagement
Low: tangential relevance or distraction indicators
validation_examples: Low: 'This doesn't really matter to me'

properties.name: ability_to_process
properties.description: Recipient's capacity to engage with argument quality

operationalization.measurement_approach: Assess knowledge indicators, comprehension signals, cognitive resources
boundary_rules: Low: lack of knowledge OR comprehension problems OR distraction
validation_examples: High: Demonstrates understanding of technical concepts
Low: Confusion about basic terms or concepts

relationships.name: processing_route_selection
relationships.description: How motivation and ability determine central vs peripheral processing

properties.name: route_determination
properties.description: Central if high motivation AND ability, peripheral otherwise

relationships.name: attitude_change_process
relationships.description: How processing route affects attitude change characteristics

properties.name: change_mechanism
properties.description: Central route: argument evaluation, Peripheral route: cue-based inference

stage_1_structuring.description: Extract ALL theory-relevant content without evaluation filtering to prevent premature pattern elimination

llm_prompts.structuring_prompt:
Apply Elaboration Likelihood Model comprehensively to extract ALL persuasion-relevant content:

1. PERSUASIVE MESSAGES: Identify all content that could be persuasive - arguments, evidence, claims, recommendations
2. ARGUMENT STRENGTH: Assess logical structure, evidence quality, reasoning coherence for each persuasive element
3. PERIPHERAL CUES: Extract all non-argument factors - source credibility, attractiveness, popularity, authority indicators
4. RECIPIENT CHARACTERISTICS: Identify motivation indicators (personal relevance, engagement) and ability indicators (knowledge, comprehension)
5. PROCESSING INDICATORS: Look for signs of careful evaluation vs quick judgments
6. ATTITUDE CHANGE EVIDENCE: Extract any attitude expressions, preference changes, decision outcomes

Do NOT filter based on whether patterns seem 'typical' for ELM - extract everything the theory would consider relevant to persuasion processes.
llm_prompts.applicability_prompt:
Assess ELM applicability to this text (score 0-1):

APPLICABILITY = Density × Centrality × Theoretical Relevance

• DENSITY: How much of the text involves persuasion-relevant phenomena? (persuasive content, attitude change, processing indicators)
• CENTRALITY: How central are persuasion processes to the text's main purpose and content?
• THEORETICAL RELEVANCE: How well do observed patterns fit ELM's explanatory scope (individual attitude change through message processing)?

Provide score and detailed reasoning explaining why this text is/isn't suitable for ELM analysis.
llm_prompts.validation_prompt: Verify that the ELM extraction is comprehensive within theory bounds and that the applicability score accurately reflects the actual density of persuasion-relevant concepts in the text.

stage_2_evaluation.description: Apply analytic questions to comprehensive structured data to extract theoretical insights

llm_prompts.evaluation_prompt:
Using the comprehensive ELM structure from Stage 1, analyze the persuasion process in this text:

1. PROCESSING ROUTE ANALYSIS: Based on motivation and ability indicators, which processing route(s) were likely used? What evidence supports this?

2. PERSUASION MECHANISM: How did the persuasion work? Through argument evaluation (central route) or peripheral cues (peripheral route)?

3. EFFECTIVENESS PREDICTION: Based on the processing route, what does ELM predict about the attitude change? (durability, resistance, accessibility)

4. THEORETICAL INSIGHTS: What does ELM reveal about this persuasion attempt that surface analysis might miss? Focus on the relationship between processing conditions and persuasion mechanisms.

Answer based on the theoretical structure, not obvious surface features.
llm_prompts.integration_prompt: Integrate findings across all ELM components (message, recipient, processing, outcomes) to provide a coherent theoretical account of how persuasion functioned in this case.

telos.purpose: Explain attitude change through identification of processing routes and persuasion mechanisms
telos.output_format: Processing route analysis with mechanism identification and effectiveness prediction
success_criteria: Processing route clearly identified with supporting evidence
Theoretical predictions about attitude change characteristics provided
Analysis reveals insights beyond surface-level observations

theory_tests.input_scenario: Text with personally relevant topic and strong logical arguments
theory_tests.expected_theory_application: Central route processing, argument-based attitude change
theory_tests.validation_criteria: Should identify high motivation, strong arguments, central processing indicators

theory_tests.input_scenario: Text with low personal relevance but high source credibility
theory_tests.expected_theory_application: Peripheral route processing, cue-based attitude change
theory_tests.validation_criteria: Should identify low motivation, peripheral cues, peripheral processing indicators

boundary_cases.case_description: Text with information but no persuasive intent
boundary_cases.expected_behavior: Low applicability score, limited persuasion-relevant extraction

boundary_cases.theory_applicability: Low - ELM focuses on individual-level processing
boundary_cases.expected_behavior: May extract individual elements but miss group-level dynamics
